Soledade C.S. Santos Ester F.G. Barbosa ⁎ Centro de Química e Bioquímica, DQB, Faculdade de Ciências, Universidade de Lisboa, 1749-016 Lisboa, Portugal ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Silver dual role as electrophilic activator and structural promoter was scrutinized using a multistep kinetic model comprising thermodynamic and kinetic steps. The quantitative evaluation of kinetic and surface parameters, for the homogeneous and heterogeneous pathways, provided clear evidence of electrophilic activation and catalysis, smeared by stereochemical packing constraints with increasing alkyl iodide chain length. A kinetic study of the silver(I) activated homogeneous and heterogeneous quaternization of coordinated triethylamine by butyl iodide in toluene was performed. Silver iodide was used as solid catalyst. The experimental data was analysed resorting to the multistep kinetic model previously proposed by Santos and Barbosa for the same reaction with ethyl iodide. The solution quaternization rate constant, k Q and the surface quaternization parameter k ′ Q b E t 3 NAgN O 3 were obtained together with estimates of the adsorption coefficients, b BuI and b EtI, for the alkyl iodides on the solid. The presence of a competitive solution reaction between silver nitrate and the alkyl halide was confirmed and its solution rate constant, k C, calculated. The data shows silver(I) coordination lead to large increases in the surface and solution amine quaternization rates. A comparison with results previously obtained for the same reaction with ethyl iodide allowed further understanding about the effect of coordinated silver nitrate ion pairs on the quaternization processes. Silver dual role as an electrophilic activator and as a structural promoter was scrutinized through a comparison of rate constants ratios with increasing alkyl chain length. Clear evidence of an electrophilic activation progressively smeared by stereochemical packing constraints in the solution and superficial transition states was obtained. Keywords Silver(I) activation Surface catalysed amine quaternization Multistep kinetic model Concerted molecular arrangement Stereoelectronic effects 1 Introduction Understanding chemical and biochemical processes in structured environments or molecular tailoring over surfaces, imparting selectivity by geometric constraints, are key issues for the development of new methodologies in science and technology, namely in the synthesis of nanoparticles or ionic liquids, and in the development of biosensors or industrial catalysts [1–3]. Quaternary ammonium salts have been the focus of numerous studies over the last century, in view of their applications as surfactants or phase transfer catalysts, but the latest potentialities in battery technology or in green chemistry [4,5], re-emerged the interest on the development of new synthetic routes, as Menschutkin's reaction involving a nucleophilic attack of an amine on an alkyl halides, is an invariably slow process. Increased reactivity and selectivity profiles have been the object of numerous approaches since sponsoring the formation of reaction intermediates by electronic or stereochemical effects may render changes, either on the nucleophilicity of the attacking group or on the leaving group ability. Alkyl halide carbon–halogen bond activation by metallic surfaces and/or ions has been frequently addressed [6–9], while nitrogen quaternization has been tackled resorting to reactions under strained environment conditions, imposed by a surface, a supramolecular cage, or resorting to “one pot reactions” involving amides as a starting materials [2,10–12]. Our previous studies on the joint homogeneous–heterogeneous catalysis of amine quaternization by ethyl iodide may be included in the former type of approach to amine quaternization, with silver ion simultaneously promoting carbon–halogen dissociation and adequate stereochemical fit for the attack of the amine electron pair [12–14]. In these studies the surface may be envisaged as functionalized by adsorbed species, loosely immobilized on adequate surface sites (Scheme 1 ) which impose a structured environment favoring amine quaternization. The quantitative evaluation of kinetic and surface parameters for this complex reaction process involved the identification of reaction products, the simultaneous assessment of several reagent reaction rates as well as silver–amine complexation constants and adsorption studies. This knowledge provided the tools for the construction of a global scheme, leading to the evaluation of solution and surface parameters. In this work the same approach was used with a longer alkyl halide, namely butyl iodide. This study comprises the calculation of solution and surface parameters k Q, k C, k ′ Q b E t 3 NAgN O 3 , b BuI, its comparison with the ones previously obtained for EtI, the consolidation of the kinetic model employed and a discussion about the relative balance of electrophilic and steric effects associated with coordinated silver [2,10–16]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and solutions Nominal purity of solvent, Toluene BDH Aristar grade, and reagents, Triethylamine, Merck-p. synthesis, Butyl iodide BDH-GPR grade, was checked by GC, being 99.98% for the solvent toluene, 84.94% for triethylamine and 99,75% for butyl iodide. Consequently, Toluene and Butyl iodide were used without further purification, but Triethylamine was purified as previously described [13,14,17,20] its final quality as checked by GC was 99.94%. Silver nitrate GPR grade (purity≥99.8%) was supplied by BDH and was used without further purification. Silver iodide was synthesised before each run according to a procedure formerly described [13,14,18–20]. The polycrystalline solid obtained was predominantly composed of β-AgI and had a BET (N2) specific surface area of 0.407±0.003m2 g−1. The amine and butyl iodide solutions in toluene were prepared, by weight, in volumetric flasks and under a light N2 flux as previously described [13,14]. 2.2 Kinetic runs The kinetic experiments were performed at 25.0±0.05°C, under constant stirring resorting to previously described procedures and experimental set up. The kinetic runs were monitored collecting reaction mixture samples and independently determining, the amine and silver content by potentiometric back titration, as formerly discussed [13]. The collected volumes were corrected for the amount of solid present, by iterative fit, resorting to mass balance equations, and densities of the solid reaction products. Kinetic runs, in the absence of silver, were also performed monitoring the amine content, in order to obtain an estimate of second order rate constants for the corresponding Menschutkin reactions. The experimental data used to evaluate the relevant kinetic parameters, for the overall reaction process, E t 3 N + E t 3 NA g + N O 3 − + R I ⟶ AgI R E t 3 N + N O 3 − + Ag I ↓ + R E t 3 N + I − was obtained under various experimental conditions, namely in the presence and absence of an initial amount of solid silver iodide, for different triethylamine/silver nitrate ratios as well as various alkyl iodide concentrations. A summary of the initial experimental conditions of all the kinetic runs considered is presented in Table 1 . The experimental kinetic data, pertaining to the runs with butyl iodide, is reported as supplementary material. 3 Kinetic model Scheme 1 depicts the overall multistep reaction mechanism used to interpret the experimental data obtained. This complex reaction process comprises thermodynamic and kinetic steps in solution and on the surface [13,14]. In this model k Q and k ′ Q are, respectively, the rate constants for the solution and surface activated quaternization of the coordinated amine by the alkyl iodide, k M and k ′ M the solution and surface rate constants for the Menschutkin reaction, k C, the rate constant for the competitive solution reaction between silver nitrate and the alkyl iodide and K 1 = k 1/k −1 and K 2 = k 2/k −2 are the stepwise equilibrium constants for the formation of the 1:1 and 1:2 silver–amine complexes. The application of this model requires the evaluation of concentration time dependencies for two reactants, in this case silver and amine, as well as previous knowledge of solution equilibrium constants and the amine adsorption isotherm. 3.1 Relevant model factors and boundaries A molecular model analysis coupled with preliminary kinetic and adsorption studies [12,13,20]allows several simplifications on the rate equations: (i) the surface and solution contribution of the Menschutkin reaction, which is very slow ( k ′ M ≤ k M ≤ 3.3 × 10 − 6 ) may be neglected; (ii) the alkylation reaction of the silver amine 1:2 complex may be overlooked in view of its relatively small concentration [21]and its steric hindrance; (iii) the superficial term of the reaction between free silver nitrate and alkyl iodide, may be disregarded versus its solution counterpart, given the extremely low uncoordinated silver nitrate solution concentrations [21]. Accordingly (1) d [ AgN O 3 ] total d t ≅ d [ RI ] total d t 〉 d [ E t 3 N ] total d t with the total silver nitrate consumption being given by (2) − d [ AgN O 3 ] total d t = − d [ RI ] total d t = d x d t ≈ k Q + k C K 1 [ E t 3 N ] free × [ RI ] total − x − a s m V [ RI ] ads × [ E t 3 NAgN O 3 ] − x − [ AgN O 3 ] free 1 + K 2 [ E t 3 N ] free − a s m V [ E t 3 NAgN O 3 ] ads + k ′ Q a s m V [ R I ] ads [ E t 3 NAgN O 3 ] ads where x is the total amount of the alkyl iodide consumed in the reaction, which is equal to the simultaneously reacting soluble silver nitrate. The total amine consumption is given by (3) − d [ E t 3 N ] total d t = − d [ E t 3 NAgN O 3 ] d t = d x 1 d t ≈ k Q [ E t 3 NAgN O 3 ] − x − [ AgN O 3 ] free 1 + K 2 [ E t 3 N ] free − a s m V [ E t 3 NAgN O 3 ] ads × [ RI ] total − x − a s m V [ RI ] ads + k ′ Q a s m V [ RI ] ads [ E t 3 NAgN O 3 ] ads where the amounts adsorbed [RI]ads and [Et3NAgNO3]ads are given by Langmuir type isotherms, in view of previous work reported in the literature[18,22] and our studies on amine adsorption[20]. The amounts adsorbed in Eqs. (2) and (3) take into consideration the competitive adsorption between the alkyl halide and Et3N [12], and the non-competitive adsorption with the silver–amine complex, whose affinity is for different surface sites [12–14]. The extended equations obtained may be found in reference [14]. A critical analysis of the collected kinetic data for amine and soluble silver, leads to the identification of extended periods, encompassing a stationary free amine concentration, which allowed the integration of Eqs. (2) and (3). This feature, previously recognized in studies with ethyl iodide [13,14] was confirmed here, where the onset of these extended periods (1800–6700s) corresponding to [ E t 3 N ] free ≅ [ E t 3 N ¯ ] free ± 5 % , is signalled by t ac . Fig. 1 clearly illustrates the choice of t ac for runs 18 and 19. The integrated rate equations, valid within such reaction periods (t ≥ t ac), are: (4) ln e − ϕ x ( t ) a − x ( t ) = ln e − ϕ x ( t ac ) a − x ( t ac ) − ( ϕ a − e ) Q 2 ( t − t ac ) and (5) ln c − ϕ x 1 ( t ) g − x 1 ( t ) = ln c − ϕ x 1 ( t ac ) g − x 1 ( t ac ) − ( ϕ g − c ) Q 1 ( t − t ac ) where a is the alkyl iodide concentration at t = t ac, e = [ E t 3 NAgN O 3 ] t ac − ϕ [ AgN O 3 ] t ac , ϕ = 1 / ( 1 + K 2 [ E t 3 N ¯ ] free ) , c is the concentration of coordinated amine at t ac , g = [ RI ] t ac − [ AgN O 3 ] t ac . Q 1 and Q 2 are coefficients related to solution and surface kinetic and adsorption parameters, introduced to simplify the mathematical analysis and whose significance will be evident below. Plots of the left hand side of Eqs. (4) and (5) versus (t − t ac) show linear behaviour, with high correlation coefficients (0.991< r 2 <0.999), substantiating the model as well as its assumptions and boundaries. Fig. 2 presents such plots for run 17. 3.2 Rate constants ascertaining The evaluation of rate constants from Eqs. (4) and (5) is not trivial, in view of Q 1 and Q 2 underlying dependencies (6) Q 2 = k Q + k C K 1 [ E t 3 N ¯ ] free + k ′ Q a s m V b E t 3 NAgN O 3 c mon o E t 3 NAgN O 3 c mon o RI 1 b RI + [ RI ] t ac + φ [ E t 3 N ¯ ] free and (7) Q 1 = k Q + k ′ Q a s m V b E t 3 NAgN O 3 c mon o E t 3 NAgN O 3 c mon o RI 1 b RI + [ RI ] t ac + φ [ E t 3 N ¯ ] free where b Et3N and b RI are the corresponding Langmuir adsorption coefficients, and φ = b E t 3 N / b RI [14]. Plots of Q 1 and Q 2 versus average solid mass ( m AgI ¯ ) , 1 1 Solid AgI is formed throughout the reaction, therefore the average solid mass plotted in abscissa, includes the initial mass plus the average amount of solid formed during the reaction period. This refinement corrects all initial solid masses leading to positive abscissa even for runs initiated without AgI. for identical free amine concentrations, allow the evaluation of k Q, k C and superficial terms. Q 1 and Q 2 take a simplified form for kinetic runs under an excess of alkyl iodide, with the denominator factor 1 b RI + [ RI ] t ac + φ [ E t 3 N ¯ ] free reducing to [ RI ] t ac / θ RI , and leading to coefficients, Q 4 and Q 3 respectively. Q 1 to Q 4 values and the corresponding relevant slope related concentration, E t 3 N ¯ free , for runs 13–19, are presented in Table 2 . Figs. 3 and 4 show plots of Q i versus m AgI ¯ , initiated with and without solid AgI, and include runs obtained under an excess of butyl iodide. The intercepts of Q 2n+1 plots allow the determination of k Q while the intercepts of Q 2n lead to the evaluation of k C as K 1 and E t 3 N ¯ free are known, and surface parameters can be estimated from the slopes of the same plots 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Evaluation of kinetic and surface parameters This study confirmed that the quaternization of silver(I) coordinated amines is heterogeneously catalysed by silver iodide, and accompanied by a competitive solution reaction between uncoordinated silver nitrate ion pairs and alkyl iodide [13,14]. 4.1.1 Reaction of soluble silver nitrate with butyl iodide in toluene Estimates of the competitive solution rate constant, k C , between non-coordinated silver and alkyl iodide were obtained by direct calculation, for runs initiated in the absence of solid, bearing in mind ( Q 2 − Q 1 ) = k C / K 1 E t 3 N ¯ free and likewise ( Q 4 − Q 3 ) = k C / K 1 E t 3 N ¯ free , the calculated values are presented in Table 3 . This methodology leads to overestimates with large uncertainties, best values being obtained through the difference of the intercepts of plots of Q 2 and Q 4 versus m AgI ¯ . These plots are presented in Fig. 3 and the independent assessments of k C, obtained by extrapolation to m = 0, are also included in Table 3. The data obtained lead to k C =5.5±0.2×103 M−1 s−1, which to the best of our knowledge is the first reported value for this reaction in toluene. Reactions of alkyl and allyl halides with silver salts in polar media have been extensively studied, second order rate constants within the range of 10−2 to 10−5 M−1 s−1 being reported for the reaction of silver nitrate with alkyl iodides in acetone, methanol, ethanol, and aqueous mixtures [6–9,22–25], in particular 6.8×10−4 M−1 s−1 for AgNO3 +BuI in ethanol at t =24.5°C [23]. Hammond et al. [6] and Melendez-Andreu [25] predicted large increases on rate constants on going from hydroxylic and polar solvents to low dielectric constant and low nucleophilicity solvents, a forecast confirmed by the extremely large value just reported for AgNO3 +BuI in toluene at t =25°C. 4.1.2 Solution and surface quaternization reactions of Silver(I)coordinated triethylamine by butyl iodide in toluene Solution and surface quaternization reaction rates were determined resorting to coefficients Q 1 and Q 3, for data sets subdivided in terms of the average free amine concentration, E t 3 N ¯ free . The extrapolation of Q 1 and Q 3 to zero mass, provided values of the solution quaternization rate constant for the coordinated amine, which were included in Table 3. Good agreement between all data, allowed the calculation of k Q =1.244×10−3 ±2×10−6 M−1 s−1.The superficial contribution to the quaternization reaction, unambiguously present in Eqs. (6) and (7), and evidenced by the mass dependent plots (Figs. 3 and 4), supports the strategy used for the evaluation and definition of boundaries for surface parameters exposed in Section 3.1. These equations evidence the dependency on the various adsorption quantities namely monolayer coverage, c mon o i and adsorption coefficients, b i , of all species involved (i = Et3N, RI and Et3NAgNO3). For Et3N, both quantities were previously determined in our laboratory using the immersion technique, b E t 3 N = 618 and c mon o E t 3 N = 4.2 × 10 − 6 mol m − 2 [20]. For the alkyl halide and for the silver amine coordination compound no data is available in the literature in this solvent, nevertheless an appropriate selection of experimental conditions allows an indirect estimate of the magnitude of the halide adsorption coefficient. The similarity of Q 1 and Q 3 versus m AgI ¯ (4.6×10−4 to 6.6×10−4) slopes under different experimental conditions (8) θ BuI [ BuI ] t ac ( excess halide ) 1 1 b BuI + [ BuI ] t ac + φ [ E t 3 N ¯ ] ≅ constant indicate the adsorption coefficient for butyl iodide in this media, b BuI is smaller than 50. A better estimate obtained through iterative calculation of the experimental ratio (8), upon introduction of b BuI and its derived quantities (φ and θ BuI) lead to 22< b BuI <30. Our previous estimate of b EtI [14] was also improved resorting to this methodology and a value between 12 and 24 was obtained. This small increase in halide adsorption coefficients on going from C 2 to C 4 may be reasoned bearing in mind the attractive interactions of the alkyl iodides with an electron donating solvent [26,27]. The longer halide possesses a larger electron donating chain, thus with smaller donor–acceptor interactions with the solvent, which brings about an increased adsorption tendency. Additionally it should be mentioned that this increase in the adsorption coefficient, with alkyl chain length, is also consistent with the increase in “sticking probability”, reported for alkyl halides on metallic surfaces, with increasing alkyl chain length [28]. Further analysis of the slopes of Q 1 and Q 3 versus m AgI ¯ , having in mind the proposed b BuI, allows the calculation of the superficial term k ′ Q b E t 3 NAgN O 3 ≅ 1.3 × 10 5 m 2 mol s − 1 considering Et3N adsorption parameters [20]. A scrutiny of k C, k Q and k ′ Q b E t 3 NAgN O 3 for BuI, together with the corresponding values for EtI substantiates the multistep kinetic model proposed, as well as the selected boundaries, since the results obtained afford clear cut decreases on rate parameters, even for a small two carbon atom increase on the alkyl halide chain length. Furthermore the observed decreases do not run parallel thus enabling insight about the balance of stereochemical and electrophilic effects in all reactions. 4.2 Stereoelectronic effects A molecular model analysis suggests metal–amine coordination necessarily accomplishes the formation of reaction intermediates accommodating amine, silver ion and alkyl halide in neighbouring positions. Silver electrophilic character leads to the formation of silver–alkyl halide charge transfer intermediates, favoring the coordinated amine attack on the carbon halogen bond. Large increases in the quaternization rates (ca. 103), associated with silver coordination, are observed in Table 4 , unequivocally indicating alternative and much lower energy pathways for quaternization. Furthermore the decrease on the ratios k M(EtI)/k M(BuI) versus k Q(EtI)/k Q(BuI) evidences a levelling effect embedded in the proposed molecular arrangement. Silver activated quaternization is accompanied by a competitive side reaction of the alkyl halide with free silver nitrate. A deeper understanding about the balance between stereochemical and electrophilic effects, in the silver activated quaternization reaction, may be obtained through the comparison of the corresponding reaction rate constants of ethyl and butyl iodide with free silver nitrate. In fact if electrophilic activation of the carbon halogen bond is the relevant driving force of solution reactions, the feeble inductive effect of the alkyl chain observed on SN2 reactions of these alkyl halides on going from ethyl to butyl should smudge, while larger decreases on rate constants with increasing alkyl chain length pinpoint to stereochemical packing constraints on intermediate/s state/s. Data presented in Table 4 for the solution reactions between uncoordinated silver nitrate ion pairs and alkyl iodides clearly show a small decrease on k C, namely 1.2, ongoing from EtI to BuI. This value when compared with the corresponding ratio for the quaternization reaction, 2.8, indicates that apart from electrophilic activation of the carbon halogen bond the structural arrangement of the intermediate state is relevant in the solution quaternization reaction suggesting the possibility of minor stereochemical constraints in the intermediate state. Moreover, the formation of silver alkyl halide charge transfer complexes as well as anion role in different media, has been frequently addressed [6–9,15,16,22–25] and recent theoretical studies about anion assistance on carbon halide bond cleavage, in low dielectric solvents, predict a transition state stabilisation for SN2 mechanisms over oxidative addition pathways [29]. These results support the role of coordinated silver nitrate as structural promoter for the nucleophilic attack on the halide, through the endorsement of charge delocalization over the amine coordinated silver–halide intermediate. Concerning the surface reaction, silver–amine coordination is crucial for the amine attack on a next neighbour halide. In fact quaternization by uncoordinated amine leads to inhibition, in the presence of solids, due to the interaction of the amine lone pair with the surface [12,13]. Silver coordination instead, accomplishes simultaneously adsorption on next neighbouring surface sites and lifting of the electron lone pair one atomic layer away from the surface, rendering adequate stereochemical positioning for the surface reaction. In this case the comparison between the surface reactions with both alkyl iodides shows a decrease of 4.0 on the surface term, k ′ Q , on going from EtI to BuI, much higher than the corresponding value for the solution process, namely 2.8, reinforcing the hypothesis of stereochemical crowding in the intermediate states which are much more relevant over a bi-dimensional space. 5 Conclusions This work demonstrates the multistep homogeneous and heterogeneous molecular model used, its mathematical description and application is consistent and produces reliable results. The system investigated here, slightly different from the one previously published, tested the capacity of the model and methodology to consent rate enhancements of 103 and simultaneously distinguish between two quite similar systems, ascertaining the soundness of this approach in the analysis of complex reaction networks with homogeneous and heterogeneous steps. Focus on the quaternization of tertiary amines, activated by silver ions and catalysed by a surface, assigns additional significance to this work in view of current interest in the quaternization of amines as well as on homo/heterogeneous processes. New kinetic and surface parameters are presented, together with the corresponding uncertainties, allowing a thorough discussion of the experimental results. Further insight about the dual role of coordinated silver in these systems (electrophilic activator and structural promoter) resulted from the comparison with previously reported data for EtI, enabling a quantitative evaluation of relative steric constraints in solution and surface transition states during reaction. Moreover, in this study homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyses, usually presented separately, are worked out together in an integrated manner, making this contribution, to the best of our knowledge, the most extensive of its kind reported in the literature. Finally, attention must be drawn to the fact that the multistep molecular model exposed here has potential application in other complex network systems where coordination occurs as well as in cases where superficial pathways should not be disregarded. coredata.dc:description: A kinetic study of the silver(I) activated homogeneous and heterogeneous quaternization of coordinated triethylamine by butyl iodide in toluene was performed. Silver iodide was used as solid catalyst. The experimental data was analysed resorting to the multistep kinetic model previously proposed by Santos and Barbosa for the same reaction with ethyl iodide. The solution quaternization rate constant, k Q and the surface quaternization parameter k ′ Q b E t 3 NAgN O 3 were obtained together with estimates of the adsorption coefficients, b BuI and b EtI, for the alkyl iodides on the solid. The presence of a competitive solution reaction between silver nitrate and the alkyl halide was confirmed and its solution rate constant, k C, calculated. The data shows silver(I) coordination lead to large increases in the surface and solution amine quaternization rates. A comparison with results previously obtained for the same reaction with ethyl iodide allowed further understanding about the effect of coordinated silver nitrate ion pairs on the quaternization processes. Silver dual role as an electrophilic activator and as a structural promoter was scrutinized through a comparison of rate constants ratios with increasing alkyl chain length. Clear evidence of an electrophilic activation progressively smeared by stereochemical packing constraints in the solution and superficial transition states was obtained.
coredata.dc:title: Silver(I) activated quaternization of triethylamine by alkyl iodides: Kinetic model and stereoelectronic effects
